Flat Cancellation in India: Process, Refunds, Legal Rights, and Financial Implications
Flat Cancellation in India: Process, Refunds, Legal Rights, and Financial Implications
Buying a flat is a major financial milestone for most individuals.However, sometimes unforeseen circumstances—such as financial constraints, project delays, or a change in personal or investment plans—may lead to the cancellation of a flat purchase.Whether you’re a first-time buyer or an experienced investor, it’s essential to understand the financial, legal, and procedural implications of flat cancellation to avoid unnecessary losses or disputes.This comprehensive blog explains the types of flat cancellations, refund rules under RERA, GST implications, buyer rights, and practical steps to manage the process smoothly.What Does Cancellation of a Flat Mean?The cancellation of a flat refers to the termination of a purchase or booking agreement for a residential or commercial unit.This cancellation can occur either before or after the execution of the sale agreement, depending on the stage of the transaction.Common Reasons for Flat Cancellations:
Financial Constraints: Difficulty in securing home loan approvals, managing EMIs, or facing unexpected financial setbacks.Delays in Project Completion: Developers failing to deliver the project within the committed timeline.Legal or Documentation Issues: Problems related to land ownership, missing approvals, or non-compliance with RERA regulations.Change in Buyer Preferences: Buyers may reconsider due to changing priorities, shifting locations, or investment diversification.Flat cancellation involves financial losses, contractual obligations, and tax implications.Being aware of these aspects beforehand helps in taking informed decisions and ensures compliance with RERA and GST regulations.Types of Flat Cancellation
a.Before Agreement Execution:
Scenario: Cancellation before signing the sale or builder-buyer agreement.Impact: In such cases, the token or booking amount may be forfeited as per the developer’s policy.b.After Agreement Execution:
Scenario: Cancellation after the sale agreement is signed.Impact: Buyers may face legal and financial implications, such as deductions for administrative or documentation costs.c. Flat Cancellation in Under-Construction Projects:
Challenges: Cancellations during construction can be complex due to payment schedules, delays, or developer defaults.

d. Flat Cancellation in OC-Received Properties:
Implications: For ready-to-move or resale flats, buyers may prefer resale or property transfer instead of cancellation to avoid charges.Cancellation Policies of Developers
a.Standard Cancellation Charges
Developers generally charge 5% to 10% of the total property value as cancellation fees.b.Refund Timelines
Refunds are typically processed within 30 to 90 days, depending on the builder’s policy and contractual terms.c. Developer-Specific Policies
Cancellation charges and refund terms vary across developers and states.Under RERA, however, buyers are protected against unfair deductions and delayed refunds, especially when cancellations occur due to project delays or non-compliance.Financial Implications of Flat Cancellation
a. Booking Amount Refund
Refund eligibility depends on the terms mentioned in the sale agreement.Developers may deduct administrative or marketing expenses before refunding the remaining amount.b.

Bank Loan Impact
Pre-Closure Charges: Home loans linked to canceled flats may attract early closure penalties.Refund of Processing Fees: Bank processing or administrative fees are typically non-refundable.c. GST and Tax Implications
For under-construction flats, GST refund may be claimed depending on whether the developer has availed input credit for the tax paid.Example:
Flat Value: ₹50,00,000
Cancellation Charges: ₹5,00,000
As per Circular 178/10/2022-GST, GST is not applicable on cancellation charges, providing partial relief to buyers.Legal Rights of Buyers
a.Rights Under RERA (Real Estate Regulation and Development Act, 2016):
RERA provides robust protection to buyers.If the developer delays possession or defaults on commitments, buyers can:
Claim full refund within 45–60 days.Seek interest or compensation for delayed possession.b.Rights Under the Consumer Protection Act: Buyers can file complaints against unfair cancellation clauses or excessive deductions and seek compensation for harassment or financial loss.Always review the cancellation and refund clauses in the sale agreement before signing to understand your financial exposure and rights.Steps to Cancel a Flat in India
Review the Sale Agreement: Understand the clauses, charges, and refund timelines.Notify the Developer: Send a formal cancellation request in writing or via registered email.Provide Documentation: Submit booking receipts, sale agreements, and payment proofs.Follow Up on Refunds: Regularly communicate with the developer to ensure timely refund processing.Close Related Accounts: Cancel linked home loans and terminate associated insurance or EMI plans.Challenges in Flat Cancellation
Refund Disputes: Developers may delay payments or deduct unreasonable charges.Loan Pre-Closure Issues: Banks may impose additional fees for early loan termination.Legal Disputes: Some developers may resist cancellation or ignore refund obligations.Credit Score Impact: Premature loan closure can affect a buyer’s CIBIL or credit score.Refunds Under RERA
1.Developer Obligations: Developers must refund the buyer if the project is delayed or non-compliant with approvals.2.Buyer Obligations: If the buyer initiates cancellation voluntarily, deductions may apply as per the agreement.3.Refund Timelines: Under RERA, refunds must be completed within 45–60 days for eligible cases.4.Filing Complaints: Buyers can file a RERA complaint online for non-compliance, delayed refunds, or illegal deductions.

Alternatives to Flat Cancellation
Flat Resale: Sell the booked flat to another buyer to avoid cancellation losses.Negotiation with Developer: Request transfer to another unit or project.Loan Restructuring: Adjust the loan tenure or EMI to ease the financial burden instead of canceling.State-Specific Rules for Flat Cancellation
Maharashtra: MahaRERA mandates strict refund timelines for project delays.Karnataka: Developers must disclose cancellation policies upfront.Tamil Nadu: The Tamil Nadu RERA Act enforces transparency in cancellation and refund terms.Delhi NCR: Strong consumer protection laws favor buyers in refund-related disputes.Practical Examples
Under-Construction Flat Cancellation Due to Delay: Full refund without deductions under RERA.GST Refund Post Agreement Execution: GST adjusted in the buyer’s refund as per developer policy.Legal Action Under RERA: Filing a complaint against unfair practices or delayed refunds.

Tips for Buyers Considering Cancellation
Review the Agreement: Study the cancellation clause carefully before signing. Communicate Clearly: Discuss refund policies and timelines with the builder. Maintain Documentation: Keep copies of all payment proofs, agreements, and correspondence. Seek Legal Advice: Consult a real estate lawyer for complex cases or disputes. Explore Alternatives: Evaluate resale or transfer options before initiating cancellation. Flat cancellation, though often unavoidable, can be managed effectively if buyers are well-informed about their legal rights, refund entitlements, and tax implications. Whether you’re canceling due to personal reasons or project delays, reviewing your agreement, understanding RERA provisions, and maintaining proper documentation will protect your interests. Always seek professional advice from real estate lawyers or financial consultants to ensure a smooth and fair resolution. Disclaimer: This blog is for informational purposes only and does not constitute legal or financial advice. Buyers should consult professionals for personalized guidance. FAQs
What are the standard cancellation charges for flats in India? Typically, 5% to 10% of the total property value. How long does it take to get a refund after flat cancellation? Refunds are usually processed within 30–90 days, depending on the builder’s policy. Can GST paid on under-construction flats be refunded upon cancellation? Yes, GST refund is possible if the flat is canceled before possession and credit is unutilized. What rights do buyers have under RERA for flat cancellation? Buyers can claim a full refund without deductions for project delays or builder default. Can I cancel a flat if the project is delayed beyond the promised timeline? Yes, RERA allows cancellations in such cases, with complete refund and interest.

Understanding GST in Real Estate: Applicability, Rates, and Implications
GST Rates on Under-Construction and OC-Received Properties: A Comprehensive Guide
The introduction of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) has significantly restructured India’s tax landscape, especially within the real estate sector.For both developers and property buyers, understanding how GST applies to under-construction and OC (Occupancy Certificate)-received properties is crucial.GST in the real estate sector of India has helped home buyers, investors, and developers clearly understand how GST affects property purchase, sale, and construction costs.In this blog, we’ll explain in detail the applicability, rates, and implications of GST on real estate transactions — covering both residential and commercial properties — to help you make better-informed property decisions.What is GST (Goods and Services Tax) in Real Estate?GST is a unified indirect tax imposed on the supply of goods and services, which includes certain real estate transactions.It was introduced to simplify the previously complicated tax structure that included multiple indirect taxes like VAT, service tax, and excise duty.By replacing these with a single tax framework, GST has made the taxation process more transparent and streamlined across India.In the context of real estate, GST applies to transactions involving under-construction flats, residential apartments, and commercial properties, ensuring a uniform tax rate across the country.Applicability of GST in Property Transactions
GST applies differently depending on whether a property is under construction or already completed.Applicable: Under-construction properties or those that have not yet received an Occupancy Certificate (OC).Not Applicable: Completed or resale properties that already have an OC.This means GST is mainly relevant during the construction phase and not after the property is deemed complete by the concerned authority.Therefore, when buyers search for properties, it’s important to know whether the property is under construction or has an occupancy certificate, as GST applicability directly depends on this factor.Difference in GST Applicability: Under-Construction vs OC-Received Properties
Under-Construction Properties: GST is levied on the total sale consideration, excluding stamp duty and registration charges.This makes the tax applicable to the base property cost.

OC-Received Properties: These are considered completed constructions and are therefore exempt from GST.Buyers of such properties only need to pay stamp duty and registration fees.GST Applicability on Real Estate Transactions
1.Properties Subject to GST:
Under-construction residential apartments awaiting OC.Under-construction commercial spaces, including shops and office units, awaiting OC.2.Properties Exempt from GST:
Completed properties that have received an Occupancy Certificate (OC) or Completion Certificate (CC) from the municipal or development authority.Resale properties (secondary market transactions) that already have an OC or CC.GST Rates on Under-Construction Properties
The GST rate on an under-construction property depends on whether the project, as registered under RERA, qualifies as a Residential Real Estate Project (RREP) or a Real Estate Project (REP).Understanding the GST rate for under-construction properties in 2025 helps buyers estimate the total cost of ownership and plan their finances accordingly.

RREP refers to a project where the carpet area of commercial apartments does not exceed 15% of the total carpet area of all apartments.If the commercial carpet area exceeds 15%, the project is categorized as REP.
1.Residential Properties
a.Affordable Housing in RREP or REP: GST Rate: 1% (without Input Tax Credit) — Developers are required to pay this amount in cash.Criteria for Affordable Housing:
Carpet area up to 60 sq.meters in metro cities (Delhi NCR, Mumbai including MMR, Kolkata, Bengaluru, Hyderabad, Chennai).Carpet area up to 90 sq.meters in non-metro cities.The total property value, including parking, development, preferred location, and common facility charges, should not exceed ₹45 lakhs.b. Non-Affordable Housing in RREP: GST Rate: 5% (without Input Tax Credit), payable in cash by the developer.2.Commercial Properties in REP
GST Rate: 18% with a one-third deduction for land value, making the effective rate 12% on the total consideration.Developers of such projects are eligible to claim Input Tax Credit (ITC) on GST paid for inputs, input services, and capital goods.Example of GST Calculation
Affordable Housing:
For a flat priced at ₹30,00,000
→ GST = 1% × 30,00,000 = ₹30,000
Non-Affordable Housing:
For a property priced at ₹80,00,000
→ GST = 5% × 80,00,000 = ₹4,00,000
These GST calculations play a crucial role for anyone planning to buy an apartment during the construction stage, as GST on new flats directly influences the final property price.GST on OC-Received Properties
a.Why GST is Not Applicable on OC-Received Properties:
As per GST law, once a property receives an Occupancy Certificate, it is no longer considered a “supply of goods or services.” Therefore, GST does not apply to such transactions.Many buyers prefer OC-received or ready-to-move properties to avoid paying GST, which makes understanding the difference between GST on under-construction and ready-to-move properties vital.b.Impact on Buyers:
For OC-received properties, buyers only pay stamp duty and registration charges, which reduces the overall cost of acquisition.Components of GST on Under-Construction Properties
GST is not levied on the full property price.Instead, it is applied only to the construction cost, after deducting the notional value of the land.Land Value Deduction: One-third (1/3rd) of the total property value is considered the land cost and excluded from GST calculations.

Example of GST Calculation:
Total property price = ₹60,00,000
Land value = (1/3 × 60,00,000) = ₹20,00,000
Taxable value = 60,00,000 − 20,00,000 = ₹40,00,000
GST at 5% = 5% × 40,00,000 = ₹2,00,000
Input Tax Credit (ITC) and Its Removal
a.What is Input Tax Credit (ITC)?ITC allows developers to claim credit for GST paid on construction-related inputs such as cement, steel, and other building materials.It helps avoid double taxation by allowing credit for taxes already paid on inputs.b.Removal of ITC for Residential Properties:
To simplify taxation and curb misuse, the government removed ITC for residential properties.Developers can no longer claim ITC for GST paid on inputs, input services, or capital goods used in constructing residential units.c. Impact of ITC Removal:
Without ITC, developers must absorb the GST cost on their inputs, which increases their overall cost.Consequently, property prices for under-construction homes have seen a slight rise.

The removal of ITC in residential real estate has been one of the most discussed changes under the GST regime, affecting both developers’ pricing strategies and homebuyers’ cost expectations.However, ITC continues to be available for under-construction commercial properties classified as REP.
Other Taxes and Charges Along with GST
Even after GST, buyers still need to account for other charges:
Stamp Duty: Varies by state, typically between 4% to 10%.Registration Charges: Generally 1% of the property’s value.In the pre-GST era, buyers had to pay several indirect taxes such as VAT and service tax.GST has now replaced these, creating a unified and more straightforward tax system.State-Specific GST and Real Estate Policies
Definitions of affordable housing and their value limits can differ slightly across states.Examples:
Maharashtra: Affordable housing GST at 1% applies to major cities such as Mumbai and Pune.Karnataka: In cities like Bengaluru, the GST impact on under-construction properties is higher due to higher property values.Reverse Charge Mechanism (RCM) in Real Estate
What is RCM?Under the Reverse Charge Mechanism, the recipient of goods or services pays GST directly to the government instead of the supplier.Applicability in Real Estate: RCM often applies to Joint Development Agreements (JDAs) and landowner-developer arrangements, where the landowner transfers development rights to the developer in exchange for constructed property or revenue share.Challenges and Common Misconceptions
Confusion often arises about whether GST applies to OC-received properties.Many buyers misunderstand the exact criteria that define affordable housing.There’s also limited awareness regarding the removal of ITC for residential properties.Educating both buyers and developers about these aspects is essential to ensure compliance and avoid financial miscalculations.Impact of GST on Property Buyers and Developers
For Buyers: GST has brought greater transparency and clarity in taxation.However, it has also increased the cost of purchasing under-construction properties since GST adds an additional layer to the final price.For Developers: Developers face challenges in pricing properties after the removal of ITC.They must also ensure strict compliance with GST filing and payment regulations, making tax management more complex but structured.Future Outlook for GST in Real Estate
The government continues to evaluate GST’s impact on housing.

There are ongoing discussions about reintroducing ITC for affordable housing projects.Authorities may consider adjusting GST rates to promote housing affordability.In the long term, GST is expected to further enhance transparency, compliance, and efficiency within the real estate ecosystem.Overall, GST has made property taxation in India more transparent, and understanding GST on real estate transactions is key for both investors and first-time homebuyers in 2025.With GST continuing to shape the Indian real estate sector, staying informed about GST updates, property tax changes, and government reforms will help buyers make better investment choices.GST has brought transparency, uniformity, and structure to real estate taxation, especially for under-construction properties.While it simplifies the overall tax framework, buyers must carefully consider the additional GST costs when purchasing such properties.

Having a clear understanding of applicable rates, exemptions, and their implications is essential for making smart investment decisions. Buyers are advised to consult developers and tax professionals to ensure complete clarity on GST compliance and cost breakdowns. Disclaimer:This blog provides general information and should not be considered legal or financial advice. Always seek professional guidance for property-specific or tax-related queries. FAQs
What is the GST rate on under-construction residential properties in India? 1% for affordable housing and 5% for non-affordable housing. Is GST applicable to resale properties? No, resale properties are exempt from GST. How is GST calculated on an under-construction flat? GST is calculated on the property value after deducting one-third of the value as land cost. What is the definition of affordable housing under GST rules? Homes with a carpet area up to 60 sq. meters in metro cities or 90 sq. meters in non-metro cities and priced below ₹45 lakhs. Why is there no GST on OC-received properties? Because such properties are treated as completed constructions and not as a supply of goods or services.

Comprehensive Guide to Renting Out Immovable Property in India
Renting out immovable property—whether residential, commercial, or industrial—is a well-established practice in the Indian real estate sector.However, this process involves several legal, financial, and tax considerations that both landlords and tenants must clearly understand to ensure seamless and compliant transactions.This comprehensive guide explores the process, obligations, and challenges involved in renting out property in India while highlighting the key legal and tax aspects every property owner and tenant should be aware of.What Does Renting Out Immovable Property Mean?Renting refers to the act of leasing out a property to a tenant in exchange for periodic rent payments.The arrangement can involve various categories of properties depending on the intended use and type of occupants.The primary types of properties that can be rented include:
Residential Properties: Flats, independent houses, or villas leased to individuals or families for dwelling purposes.Commercial Properties: Shops, office spaces, or co-working spaces used for business and professional activities.Industrial Properties: Warehouses, factories, or industrial units used for manufacturing or storage purposes.Understanding these distinctions is crucial, as each category involves different legal frameworks, taxation rules, and compliance requirements.Having proper knowledge of rental agreements, tenant rights, tax liabilities, and applicable state laws helps both landlords and tenants maintain transparency and avoid potential disputes.It ensures compliance with statutory obligations, protects financial interests, and contributes to smoother rental transactions.Types of Rental Agreements
1) Residential Lease Agreement
Features: Typically short-term in nature, usually lasting for 11 months, which helps landlords avoid the complex provisions of long-term tenancy laws.Terms: The agreement includes details such as rent amount, security deposit, maintenance charges, renewal conditions, and notice period.2) Commercial Lease Agreement
Differences from Residential Leases: Usually has a longer tenure and includes specific clauses tailored for business operations.It may require higher security deposits and contains detailed conditions related to usage and maintenance.Clauses: Provisions for subletting, signage rights, alterations, and commercial usage terms are commonly included to ensure business continuity.

3) Leave and License Agreement
Definition: A contractual arrangement granting a tenant permission to use the property without transferring tenancy rights.Popularity: This structure is especially preferred in metropolitan cities like Mumbai, Delhi, and Bengaluru for short-term stays or temporary arrangements, as it provides flexibility and easier termination options.Steps to Rent Out Immovable Property
Step 1: Prepare the Property – Ensure that the property is clean, habitable, and compliant with safety regulations before listing it for rent.Conduct necessary repairs and consider adding value through furniture, fixtures, or air conditioning to attract better tenants.Step 2: Find Suitable Tenants – Advertise the property through reputed online real estate portals, local brokers, or word-of-mouth referrals.It is important to perform background verification and police checks to assess the reliability of potential tenants.

Step 3: Draft a Rental Agreement – A well-drafted rental agreement should include key clauses such as rent amount, payment frequency, security deposit, maintenance obligations, renewal conditions, and termination terms.Step 4: Register the Rental Agreement – To make the agreement legally valid and enforceable, register it under the respective state’s Registration Act.Pay applicable stamp duty and registration fees as prescribed by state laws.Step 5: Handover and Documentation – During possession handover, provide property keys and an inventory list (especially for furnished properties).Maintain copies of all signed documents and payment records to ensure complete transparency and legal safety.Rental Income and Taxes
Rental income refers to any income earned by leasing out a property.It is taxable under the head “Income from House Property” as per the Income Tax Act, 1961.
a) Taxation of Rental Income
Standard Deduction: A flat 30% deduction of the annual rental income is allowed towards maintenance and repair expenses, irrespective of actual costs incurred.Property Tax Deduction: Property tax paid by the landlord during the financial year can be deducted, provided it has been actually paid and not merely accrued.Net Taxable Rental Income: Net Rental Income = Gross Rent − (30% Standard Deduction + Property Tax Paid)
b) Tax Deducted at Source (TDS) on Rentals
If the tenant or lessee is not an individual or HUF, they must deduct TDS at 10% when monthly rent exceeds ₹50,000.If the tenant is an individual or HUF, TDS must still be deducted if their gross receipts in the preceding financial year exceed ₹1 crore from business or ₹50 lakhs from profession.GST on Commercial Rentals
Under GST law, a landlord or lessor must obtain GST registration if their aggregate turnover exceeds ₹20 lakhs in a financial year.Once registered, GST is applicable on rental income, and the landlord must issue a tax invoice (e-invoice) to the tenant.Example: If a commercial property is rented for ₹25 lakhs annually, GST at 18% will apply to the total rent amount.It is important to note that GST does not apply on refundable security deposits collected by the landlord.If the landlord is not registered under GST but the tenant is registered, and the property is not residential, GST is payable by the tenant under the Reverse Charge Mechanism (RCM) as per Entry 5AB of Notification 13/2017, dated 28th June 2017.

Legal Obligations and Compliance
Tenant Verification
Landlords must conduct police verification to ensure tenant safety and prevent misuse of the property.This process also helps avoid potential legal issues in case of disputes.Registration of Rental Agreements
Rental agreements exceeding 11 months must be legally registered.Non-registration can result in the agreement being unenforceable and may expose the parties to legal risks and penalties.Eviction Laws
Evictions must follow due legal process, typically involving notice periods and valid grounds such as non-payment of rent, misuse of property, or breach of agreement terms.Responsibilities of the Landlord
Provide a safe, livable, and well-maintained property.Address repair and maintenance issues promptly.Manage security deposits responsibly, ensuring timely refunds after adjusting legitimate dues.Responsibilities of the Tenant
Pay rent on time and adhere to all terms of the rental agreement.Keep the property clean and well-maintained.Notify the landlord immediately in case of damages or repair requirements.

Common Clauses in a Rental Agreement
Rent and Security Deposit: Define the rent amount, payment schedule, and conditions for refund or adjustment of the security deposit.Maintenance Responsibilities: Specify whether the landlord or tenant will bear maintenance and repair costs.Lock-in Period: Mention a minimum duration within which neither party can terminate the agreement.Termination Clause: Outline the notice period and conditions for vacating the property.State-Specific Rental Laws
Maharashtra Rent Control Act: Safeguards tenant rights and regulates rent revisions.Delhi Rent Control Act: Governs security deposit norms and eviction processes.Tamil Nadu Regulation of Landlords and Tenants Act: Defines balanced responsibilities between landlords and tenants.Factors That Affect Rental Value
Location: Proximity to schools, markets, workplaces, and transport hubs.Type of Property: Furnished or semi-furnished properties often fetch higher rents.Market Trends: Rental demand in urban centers can fluctuate with job growth and migration.Amenities: Parking, power backup, and security features significantly influence rent value.Challenges in Renting Out Property
Tenants defaulting on rent payments.Disputes over security deposit refunds.Property damage or misuse by tenants.Delays in rent collection or eviction proceedings.Tips for Landlords
Conduct thorough tenant screening before finalizing agreements.Draft detailed and legally sound rental contracts.Keep records of rent receipts, maintenance expenses, and communication.Schedule periodic inspections to ensure property upkeep.Rental Trends in India
Increasing rental demand in metropolitan cities due to urban migration and job opportunities.Growth of co-living and shared accommodation spaces driven by young professionals and students.The work-from-home trend has influenced rental preferences, with many tenants seeking larger spaces or properties in suburban areas.Renting out immovable property can be a profitable and stable income source when managed responsibly.A sound understanding of rental agreements, compliance requirements, and tax implications ensures smooth operations and minimizes disputes.Landlords and tenants are advised to consult legal and tax professionals for complex transactions to safeguard their interests.For more information, contact us today.Disclaimer: This blog provides general information for educational purposes only and does not constitute legal or financial advice.

Readers should seek professional guidance for specific situations.FAQs
Is rental income taxable in India?Yes, rental income is taxable under the head “Income from House Property.”
What is the maximum deposit a landlord can collect?It varies by state but typically ranges from two to three months’ rent.How should disputes between landlords and tenants be resolved?Disputes can be resolved through mutual discussion or, if unresolved, by taking legal action under the Rent Control Act.What happens if the rental agreement is not registered?An unregistered rental agreement is not legally enforceable and can lead to disputes or financial losses.Are there any tax benefits for landlords?Yes, landlords can claim deductions for maintenance expenses and property taxes when calculating taxable income.

How Does Our EMI Calculator Work?Our EMI calculator simplifies complex financial calculations into a few easy steps.All you need to do is input three basic details:
Principal Loan Amount (P): This is the total amount of money you wish to borrow from the bank or financial institution.Interest Rate (R): This is the annual interest rate charged by the lender on your loan.Loan Tenure (N): This is the total duration, in months or years, over which you plan to repay your loan.Once you enter these values, our calculator instantly computes your monthly EMI using the following formula:
EMI = P × R × (1 + R)^N / ((1 + R)^N – 1)
Where
P = Principal Loan Amount
R = Monthly Interest Rate (Annual Rate / 12 / 100)
N = Loan Tenure in Months
In addition to above, you have to have a detailed understanding of your monthly financial obligations like expenses towards ongoing loans or credit card EMIs, so you get a clear picture if your financial health is capable of take care of the new loan obligation.Why Use a Home Loan EMI Calculator?Better Financial Planning: Understand your monthly outflow and compare different loan scenarios (e.g., varying loan amounts, tenures, or interest rates) to find what best suits your financial capacity.Transparency: Clearly see the breakdown of your principal and interest components over time.Save Time: No need for manual calculations or complex spreadsheets.An EMI calculator tool does the work for you.Informed Decision Making: Empower yourself with the knowledge needed to choose the right home loan product.What is an EMI?EMI stands for Equated Monthly Installment.It is a fixed payment amount made by a borrower to a lender at a specified date each month.It consists of both the principal loan amount and the interest accrued on the outstanding loan balance.Over the loan tenure, the interest component is higher in the initial EMIs and gradually decreases, while the principal component increases.Key Components of Your Home Loan EMI:
Principal Amount: The actual amount of money you borrowed from the bank.Interest Amount: The cost of borrowing money calculated based on the interest rate and the outstanding principal.Pre-EMI vs EMI: What’s the Difference?When a home loan is disbursed in parts often during property construction, borrowers usually pay Pre-EMI, which includes only the interest on the loan amount released so far.

The actual EMI (Equated Monthly Installment) starts once the full loan amount is disbursed, covering both principal and interest.In short:
Pre-EMI: Interest-only payments made before the loan’s full disbursement.EMI: Regular monthly payments including both principal and interest after full disbursement.Comparison Table
Criteria EMI Pre-EMI
Tax Benefits Available on both interest and principal Only on interest
Cash Flow Higher monthly outgo Lower monthly outgo initially
Loan Tenure Starts later Starts immediately
Factors Affecting Your Home Loan EMI
Loan Amount: A higher loan amount will naturally result in a higher EMI, assuming other factors remain constant.Interest Rate: Even a small change in the interest rate can significantly impact your EMI.Lower rates mean lower EMIs.Loan Tenure:
Longer Tenure: Reduces your monthly EMI, making it more affordable, but increases the total interest paid over the life of the loan.

Shorter Tenure: Increases your monthly EMI, but significantly reduces the total interest paid, saving you money in the long run.How to Reduce Your Overall Interest and Loan Tenure?If you want to save on interest and close your loan faster, here are some simple strategies:
Opt for a shorter tenure: While EMIs will be slightly higher, you’ll pay significantly less interest over time.Make part-prepayments: Whenever possible, pay a lump sum towards the principal.This reduces the outstanding balance and future interest burden.Refinance to a lower rate: If another bank offers a better rate, consider transferring your home loan to reduce both interest and tenure.Increase EMI amount: Even a small top-up in your monthly EMI can shorten your tenure and reduce total interest outgo.These steps can help you manage your home loan EMI smartly and save considerably in the long run.Benefits of Using a Home Loan EMI Calculator
Budgeting: Helps you allocate your monthly income to accommodate the EMI without stressing your finances.Comparison: Allows you to compare different loan offers from various lenders by inputting their respective interest rates and tenures.Prepayment Planning: While not directly calculating prepayment, understanding your EMI helps you see how much extra you might need to pay to reduce your principal faster.Stress-Free Planning: Takes the guesswork out of home loan repayment, allowing you to focus on choosing your perfect home with Mahindra Lifespaces.How to Maximize Your Savings on a Home Loan?Opt for a Shorter Tenure: If your finances allow, a shorter tenure means less interest paid overall.Make Prepayments: Any additional payments made towards the principal can significantly reduce your total interest burden and shorten your loan tenure.Look for Lower Interest Rates: Always compare offers from multiple lenders.Even a 0.25% difference can save you lakhs over decades.Maintain a Good Credit Score: A high credit score can help you negotiate for better interest rates.Mahindra Lifespaces: Helping You Plan Your Home Loan with Confidence
At Mahindra Lifespaces, we understand that buying a home is one of life’s most important financial and emotional decisions.That’s why our goal is to make every step from planning your finances to finding the perfect property seamless, transparent, and stress-free.Since 2013, we have maintained a 100% green portfolio, ensuring all our products are certified as green.

Notably, three of our projects have achieved the highest levels of green certification under the IGBC and GRIHA rating systems.These certifications have not only earned us incentives from state governments and urban local bodies but have also positioned us as industry innovators in building green homes.We are currently developing multi-family apartments within gated communities across Mumbai, Pune, Bengaluru, Chennai, and Alibaug.Our commitment to green certification builds trust with both customers and investors.Additionally, our customers benefit from a property tax rebate of up to 8%, which amounts to approximately INR 800 to INR 1,000 per dwelling unit.Our home loan EMI calculator online is just one of the many tools designed to help you make informed decisions.Along with our home loan eligibility calculator and interest rate calculator, we empower you to estimate your affordability, explore loan scenarios, and understand your repayment journey clearly.

With projects across India and partnerships with trusted financial institutions, we offer flexible solutions, competitive home loan interest rates, and complete guidance, so you can invest with confidence.Whether you’re a first-time homebuyer or looking to expand your investment portfolio, Mahindra Lifespaces ensures you have the right insights, the right tools, and the right home to begin your journey.Ready to find your dream home?While you calculate your EMIs, explore our exquisite range of properties and projects.Disclaimer: This blog provides general information and should not be considered legal or financial advice.Always seek professional guidance for property-specific or tax-related queries.FAQs
How can I check my home loan eligibility online?You can easily check your home loan eligibility using our home loan eligibility calculator.Just enter your income, loan amount, and tenure details to instantly know the amount you can borrow and plan your purchase confidently with Mahindra Lifespaces.What is a home loan interest rate calculator and how does it work?A home loan interest rate calculator helps you estimate the total interest payable on your loan based on your loan amount, tenure, and applicable interest rate.It quickly shows how different rates affect your EMI, helping you compare and choose the best option.How accurate is a home loan interest rate calculator?A home loan interest rate calculator provides highly reliable estimates based on standard EMI formulas.While actual figures may vary slightly due to processing fees or rate changes, it gives a close and dependable idea for financial planning.How do I understand my home loan repayment structure?Your home loan repayment schedule consists of both principal and interest components.Initially, a larger portion goes toward interest, but over time, the principal share increases.Our EMI calculator also shows this breakdown clearly through an amortization schedule.Can I claim tax benefits on my home loan EMI payments?Yes.Under Section 80C of the Income Tax Act, you can claim tax deductions on the principal repaid.Additionally, under Section 24(b), you can claim deductions on the interest component of your EMI, making your monthly home loan payments more tax-efficient.Disclaimer: This blog provides general information and should not be considered legal or financial advice.Always seek professional guidance for property-specific or tax-related queries.How much EMI can I afford for my income?

Use our home loan EMI calculator online to determine an EMI amount that fits comfortably within your budget and ensures stress-free repayments.Is the EMI fixed throughout the loan tenure?If you opt for a fixed interest rate loan, your EMI will remain constant.However, for floating interest rate loans, your EMI may change if the benchmark interest rate changes, leading to an adjustment in your lender's interest rate.What happens if I make a partial prepayment?Making a partial prepayment reduces your outstanding principal loan amount.This typically gives you two options: either reduce your future EMIs or keep the EMI same and reduce your loan tenure.Most financial advisors recommend reducing the tenure to save more on interest.Can I change my loan tenure after taking the loan?Yes, most banks allow you to negotiate changes to your loan tenure, especially when interest rates change or if you make significant prepayments.

However, this is subject to the bank's policies and may involve some processing fees.Disclaimer: This blog provides general information and should not be considered legal or financial advice.Always seek professional guidance for property-specific or tax-related queries.What is the ideal loan tenure?The ideal loan tenure depends on your financial capacity, age, and future income expectations.While a longer tenure offers lower EMIs, a shorter tenure saves on overall interest.It's a balance between affordability and total cost.Our calculator helps you visualize these scenarios.How is the monthly interest rate calculated from the annual interest rate for EMI?The annual interest rate (e.g., 8% per annum) is first divided by 100 to convert it into a decimal (0.08).Then, this decimal rate is divided by 12 to get the monthly interest rate.So, if the annual rate is 8%, the monthly rate (R in the formula) would be 0.08 / 12 = 0.00667.Disclaimer: This blog provides general information and should not be considered legal or financial advice.Always seek professional guidance for property-specific or tax-related queries.Can I get a home loan EMI without a down payment?Getting a home loan without any down payment is generally not possible, as most lenders require the borrower to contribute a portion of the property value upfront.The down payment demonstrates financial commitment and reduces the overall loan amount.A higher down payment can also help lower your home loan EMI and total interest cost.What is the impact of a rising interest rate on my floating home loan EMI?For a floating-rate home loan, if interest rates rise, your lender typically has two options:
Increase your EMI: Your monthly payment goes up to accommodate the higher interest cost while keeping the tenure same.Increase your loan tenure: Your EMI remains the same, but the number of remaining installments (tenure) increases to cover the higher interest.Most banks initially prefer to increase tenure.Our calculator helps you understand such scenarios by adjusting the interest rate.How do I calculate the total interest paid over the entire home loan tenure?Our EMI calculator automatically provides the total interest payable.Manually, once you have the monthly EMI, you multiply it by the total number of months in your loan tenure (EMI x N).From this total amount, you subtract the principal loan amount (P).The remaining figure is the total interest paid.

Total Interest = (EMI x Loan Tenure in Months) - Principal Loan Amount
Disclaimer: This blog provides general information and should not be considered legal or financial advice.Always seek professional guidance for property-specific or tax-related queries.What documents are typically required when applying for a home loan?While specific requirements vary by lender, common documents for buying a home include:
Identity Proof: PAN card, Aadhaar card, Passport, Voter ID.Address Proof: Aadhaar card, Passport, Utility bills (electricity, water).Income Proof (Salaried): Latest salary slips (3-6 months), Bank statements (6 months), Form 16, ITR.Income Proof (Self-Employed): Business profile, ITRs (2-3 years), P&L statement, Balance sheet, Bank statements (1 year).Property Documents: Agreement to Sell, Allotment Letter, Chain of Title deeds, NOC from builder, etc.It's always best to check with your specific lender for an exact list.Can a higher credit score help in getting a lower home loan EMI?Absolutely.

A strong credit score (generally above 750-800) indicates to lenders that you are a responsible borrower.This significantly increases your chances of loan approval and often qualifies you for more favorable terms, including a lower interest rate.A lower interest rate directly translates to a lower monthly EMI and reduced overall interest payable.Is it better to pay a higher EMI or opt for a longer tenure?This depends on your financial comfort and goals.a) Higher EMI: If you can comfortably afford it, a higher EMI (leading to a shorter tenure) will result in substantial savings on the total interest paid over the life of the loan.b) Longer Tenure: If you need to keep your monthly cash outflow low, a longer tenure provides a more affordable EMI.However, be aware that you will pay significantly more interest over the loan period.Our calculator can help you compare these scenarios.What is the difference between fixed and floating interest rates for home loans?a) Fixed Interest Rate: The interest rate remains constant throughout the loan tenure, providing predictable EMIs.This offers stability but might be higher than floating rates if market rates fall.b) Floating Interest Rate: The interest rate changes periodically based on market benchmarks (like Repo Rate).Your EMI can fluctuate (or tenure can change).While it offers the benefit of lower EMIs if rates fall, it also carries the risk of higher EMIs if rates rise.How does a home loan balance transfer impact my EMI?A home loan balance transfer involves moving your existing home loan from one lender to another, usually to get a lower interest rate.If you secure a lower interest rate, your EMI will likely decrease, or you might choose to keep the EMI same and reduce your remaining loan tenure, saving you money on interest in the long run.Disclaimer: This blog provides general information and should not be considered legal or financial advice.Always seek professional guidance for property-specific or tax-related queries.How can I reduce my current ROI if my current ROI is higher than the new home loan ROI offering?Negotiating with your existing lender, especially if you have a strong payment history.Pay the switch fee and get your high running ROI to the prevailing current ROI.The new ROI will still be a few base points higher than the new offering.Disclaimer: This blog provides general information and should not be considered legal or financial advice.

Strong H1 performance from MLDL; Continued GDV momentum and healthy PAT
Home
Press release
Strong H1 performance from MLDL; Continued GDV mom...Published: 31 Oct 2025 3 min Read Read By 55 Author: Mahindra Lifespaces Category: Results
Mumbai, Oct 31, 2025 – Mahindra Lifespace Developers Limited (MLDL), the real estate and infrastructure development business of the Mahindra Group, announced its financial results for the quarter ended 30th September 2025 today.In accordance with INDAS 115, Company recognizes its revenues on completion of contract method.Key highlights
H1 FY26:
• Consolidated Sales (Resi and IC&IC) of Rs 1419 Cr.— Gross development value additions in H1 FY26 were Rs 5,200 crore as against Rs 2,050 crore in H1 FY25 (~2.6x).— H1 FY26 residential pre-sales of Rs 1,200 crore (saleable area of 1.75 msft, RERA carpet area of 1.31 msft) as compared to Rs 1,415 crore in H1 FY25.Major launches planned in the upcoming quarters.— Consolidated revenues of Rs 219 crore in H1 FY26 from IC&IC business as against Rs 214 crore in H1 FY25 (Total leased area – 35.6 acres in H1 FY26).— The consolidated PAT, after non-controlling interest, as per INDAS is Rs 99 crore in H1 FY26 as against loss of Rs 1 crore in H1 FY25, reflecting strong Resi and IC&IC profitability.• Strong balance sheet and collections.— Net debt to equity ratio at -0.17 (cash surplus) as of 30th September 2025.— Residential collections of Rs 1,086 crore for H1 FY26 as compared to Rs 999 crore for H1 FY25.Q2 FY26:
• Consolidated Sales (Resi and IC&IC) of Rs 851 Cr.— Gross development value additions in Q2 FY26 were Rs 1,700 crore as against Rs 650 crore in Q2 FY25.— Q2 FY26 residential pre-sales of Rs 752 crore (saleable area of 1.17 msft, RERA carpet area of 0.88 msft), growth of 89% over Q2 FY25.— Consolidated revenues of Rs 99 crore in Q2 FY26 from IC&IC business as against Rs 111 crore in Q2 FY25 (Total leased area – 16.9 acres).— The consolidated PAT, after non-controlling interest, as per INDAS is Rs 48 crore in Q2 FY26 as against loss of Rs 14 crore in Q2 FY25.Commenting on the performance, Mr. Amit Kumar Sinha, Managing Director & CEO, Mahindra Lifespace Developers Ltd., said, “We are pleased to announce a strong financial performance for the first half of the fiscal year.Our BD momentum continues with year-to-date GDV additions of Rs 9,500 Cr.The IC&IC business is also seeing healthy traction across Jaipur and Chennai, suggesting growing interest from industrial clients.

Strong H1 PAT performance provides a solid foundation for continued growth in FY26.”
Notes:
1.Company uses carpet areas in its customer communication.However, the data in saleable area terms has been presented here to enable continuity of information to investors and shall not be construed to be of any relevance to home buyers / customers.2.The operational highlights include the performance of the Company and its subsidiaries / joint ventures / associates.

Phygital Library inaugurated at Reserve Police Line, Chandpole by Mahindra World City, Jaipur
Aligns with Rajasthan Govt’s broader focus on improving educational infrastructure, expanding digital learning and developing skills of the youth
Jaipur, October 29, 2025 – Mahindra World City Jaipur Ltd. (‘MWC Jaipur’), a joint venture between Mahindra Lifespace Developers Limited (MLDL) and Rajasthan State Industrial Development and Investment Corporation (RIICO), today inaugurated a new phygital library at the Reserve Police Line, Chandpole, Jaipur.The facility was dedicated to the citizens of Jaipur by Shri Ajitabh Sharma, Principal Secretary – Energy; in the presence of Shri Sachin Mittal, Commissioner of Police, Jaipur; and Shri Amit Sinha, Managing Director & CEO, Mahindra Lifespace Developers Limited.The library aligns with the Rajasthan Government’s broader initiatives to expand educational infrastructure, nurture digital learning, and enhance youth employability by supporting preparation for various competitive and government examinations.Developed under Mahindra World City Jaipur’s CSR program, the phygital library – combining both physical and digital learning resources will primarily serve police personnel and their families, while also remaining open to the public.It is expected to benefit over 5,000 citizens over time and will house books across subjects including Science, Mathematics, Arts & Literature, Competitive Exams, Skill Development, and Fiction/Non-Fiction.The facility is also integrated with the National Digital Library of India (NDLI), an initiative of the Ministry of Education, Government of India, developed by the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Kharagpur.NDLI provides access to millions of digital resources including books, journals, articles, theses, videos, and simulations across diverse disciplines making quality educational content accessible to students, teachers, researchers, and lifelong learners alike.Shri Ajitabh Sharma, Principal Secretary, Energy, Government of Rajasthan, said, “This initiative exemplifies the power of public-private collaboration in driving social progress.By enabling access to learning resources for police personnel, their families and the larger community, it strengthens the foundation of inclusive development.”
Shri Sachin Mittal, Commissioner of Police, Jaipur, said, “We deeply appreciate this thoughtful initiative.

The library will serve as a meaningful space for study, learning, and personal growth for police personnel and their families”
Shri Amit Kumar Sinha, Managing Director & CEO, Mahindra Lifespace Developers Limited, said, “We commend the Government of Rajasthan’s continued focus on educational access.This collaboration with Jaipur Police underscores our shared commitment to building inclusive and sustainable communities through education and empowerment.”
The library is part of Mahindra World City (Jaipur)’s ongoing CSR initiatives focused on education, health, environment, and skill-building.Notable initiatives include Hunnar, which has empowered 3,294 youth through 13 vocational courses since FY 2009–10, promoting livelihoods, especially among women, through training in beauty and wellness, tailoring, and other employable skills.MWC Jaipur has also partnered with Tarun Bharat Sangh (TBS) for a Water Conservation and Retention project to promote sustainable water management in nearby villages.

The initiative includes rainwater harvesting, construction of 16 farm ponds and 11 water tanks across 10 villages, conserving over 44 crore litres of water annually. This conserved rainwater is used to irrigate arid land and initiate agriculture on fallow land where cultivation of crops has been historically impossible, thereby enhancing agricultural productivity and supporting environmental conservation. Other initiatives include Green Guardians, which promotes energy efficiency through LED installations in over 7,000 rural homes, and Mahindra Hariyali, which supports sustainability through the plantation of nearly 55,000 trees in government-approved forest and rural areas. About Mahindra World City, Jaipur
Mahindra World City, Jaipur is a PPP between the Mahindra Group and Rajasthan State Industrial Development and Investment Corporation (RIICO), located off NH8 and within the influence zone of DMIC (Delhi Mumbai Industrial Corridor). Spread across 3000 acres, Mahindra World City, Jaipur is a global benchmark in sustainable development and has a Multi-Sector Special Economic Zone spread across 1500 acres, a Domestic Tariff Area (DTA) spread across 1000 acres and a proposed co-located social & residential zone planned in ~500 acres.

Mahindra Lifespaces wins Redevelopment Mandate for Four Societies in Malad (West), Mumbai, with a Potential of ~INR 800 Crore
Home
Press release
Mahindra Lifespaces wins Redevelopment Mandate for...Published: 10 Oct 2025 2 min Read Read By 161 Author: Mahindra Lifespaces Category: redevelopment
Mumbai, October 10th, 2025: Mahindra Lifespace Developers Limited (MLDL), the real estate and infrastructure development arm of the Mahindra Group, today announced that it has been selected as the preferred partner for the redevelopment of four residential societies in Malad (West), one of Mumbai’s established suburban neighbourhoods.Spread across approximately 1.65 acres, the project offers a development potential of INR ~800 crore.The project is located close to Mahindra Lifespaces’ ongoing redevelopment project, Mahindra Codename64, strengthening presence in the micro-market.Located just 2.6 km from the Western Express Highway, the project offers excellent connectivity to key parts of Mumbai via multiple transport modes.It is conveniently situated less than 1 km from Malad West Metro Station and around 1.5 km from Malad Railway Station.The location’s proximity to prominent business hubs such as Mindspace, Malad and Bandra Kurla Complex (BKC) further enhances its appeal.Mr Vimalendra Singh, Chief Business Officer – Residential, Mahindra Lifespace Developers Ltd., said, “This project further strengthens our presence in Mumbai’s redevelopment market, reflecting the trust our brand has earned over the years with customers and communities.Our reputation for delivering thoughtfully designed, high-quality homes has made us a preferred choice for societies looking to redevelop.This is also in line with our strategy of deepening presence in established micromarkets, enabling us to leverage economies of scale and enhance project efficiencies.”
Situated in an established residential area, the new development will provide easy access to a wide range of urban conveniences, including reputed schools, leading healthcare facilities, retail destinations, and business centres.With the operational Malad Metro Station in close proximity, residents will benefit from enhanced mobility and connectivity across Mumbai.Mahindra Lifespaces To Redevelop Two Housing Societies In Chembur, Mumbai With A Combined Development Potential Of ~INR 1,700 Cr
Home
Press release
Mahindra Lifespaces To Redevelop Two Housing Socie...

Published: 16 Sep 2025 2 min Read Read By 749 Author: Mahindra Lifespaces Category: Featured, Launch, redevelopment
Mumbai, September 16th, 2025: Mahindra Lifespace Developers Limited (MLDL), the real estate and infrastructure development arm of the Mahindra Group, today announced being chosen as the partner for two society redevelopment projects in Chembur, Mumbai, with a combined gross development potential of approximately INR 1,700 Cr.The two societies span ~2.6 acres and ~1.8 acres respectively.The redevelopment will deliver well-planned homes, designed with a focus on sustainability, modern amenities, and connectivity.It will offer residents an enhanced living experience while creating long-term value through thoughtful design and environmentally responsible practices.Vimalendra Singh, Chief Business Officer – Residential, Mahindra Lifespace Developers Ltd., said “Redevelopment continues to play an important role in our growth journey.It enables us to bring high-quality residential projects to neighbourhoods where demand remains strong.We are grateful for the trust the societies have placed in us, and through these projects we look forward to contributing to the growth story of Chembur.”
These projects are located in the Diamond Garden area, in Chembur.Long known for its strategic location connecting the city’s business districts with the eastern suburbs, Chembur is set to benefit further from recent announcements permitting higher redevelopment potential, enhancing long-term value creation.Situated just 1.5 kilometres from the Eastern Freeway, the projects offer direct access to Thane, Navi Mumbai and other key parts of Mumbai.Connectivity will be further strengthened by the Diamond Garden Metro Station on Line 2, along with nearby Monorail and Railway links.Proximity to business hubs such as BKC and Powai makes the location highly accessible and well-positioned for the future.

Essential Checkpoints – Mahindra Lifespaces
Open space in a residential project refers to a piece of land or area which does not have any structure or construction done on it.Open spaces can include green spaces, landscapes, parks, and community gardens, among others.At Mahindra Lifespaces, we ensure a minimum of 50% of the total land parcel is dedicated to open and green spaces.A resident is allowed to make changes without compromising the civil and structural aspects of the building and the apartment.Any change or modification should always be done in consultation with relevant experts like architects and structural engineers.Every individual has a distinct taste, and hence the choice of customization or interior design may depend on the extent of alterations intended.You may consult the society/sales manager to get an idea and an understanding of the process and evaluate accordingly.Any addition/alteration in the basic structural system shall be prohibited
The floor-to-ceiling height in most homes varies across different cities and typically ranges between 9 to 10 feet.In some cases, like penthouses or duplex homes, it goes over 10 feet.Combining two apartments is very common these days.If you are looking for a bigger home to live in with your joint family or are looking for more privacy, this provision is provided in many buildings.However, the structural and architectural feasibility needs to be checked with the developer before any changes/modifications are done.The option of the Jodi apartment is pre-decided by the developer at specific locations and cannot be combined anywhere within the building.Connectivity plays an important role in choosing the location for your home.Transport options that you or your family would need to use frequently like metro, local railway, bus service or proximity to the highway should be looked at.Other important factors to consider are the availability of schools, hospitals, malls and other social infrastructure near your home.All residential developments have to provide a certain number of car park slots basis the number of homes in the residential complex.Standard parking size for a car is 13.75 sq.m., and for two-wheeler it is 2 sq.f.; though it also varies as per different jurisdictions..Car parks in most residential projects are provided in stilt, basement, podium or MLCP (Multilevel car parking).Some projects also have mechanical car parks in the form of stack parking, puzzle parking or automated car park towers.

Mahindra Lifespaces is one of the leaders in green home development.Hence, when it comes to car parking, we also ensure that every residential project that we develop has sufficient electric car charging facility/provision.Solar electricity provision is given in many new residential developments.At Mahindra Lifespaces, all our buildings are certified green rated.Therefore, we provide solar electricity provision, which helps in reducing the electricity cost for the common area facilities.We take into consideration senior citizens and the specially-abled while designing our residential buildings.Some such features include:
Ramps alongside staircases in the common areas for easy movement of wheel chairs.Grab bars while moving up or down the staircase
Some of our recent projects also have dedicated senior citizen seating areas amidst green spaces.Yes, Mahindra projects are pet friendly.In some residential complexes, we also provide dedicated spaces for pet parks/zones.

Mahindra Lifespaces ensures the project is managed with optimal utilization of resources, materials, and processes till the time of society formation. This is done by implementation of the best in industry practices within the building environment, customer satisfaction focus, training of resources, cost-saving initiatives, budget management, compliance to IGBC and statutory requirements, predictive and preventive maintenance practices, timely repairs & rectifications, and asset management so that the project is handed over to the society/association in a well-maintained condition. In India, now most RCC framed buildings are built as per local bylaws, the National Building Code and relevant Indian Standard codes that are considered safe to withstand earthquake forces. As India is divided into various seismic zones, it is important for builders and authorities to ensure that the design complies with the relevant IS standards. There are specialized green building certification bodies like the Indian Green Building Council (IGBC), Green Rating for Integrated Habitat Assessment (GRIHA), etc. which certify a building to be a sustainable/green development. A green-certified building is one that, by its design, construction, or operation, reduces or eliminates negative impacts on our climate and natural environment. Every green building in India is carefully designed to protect valuable natural resources while also improving the quality of life of the residents. Some of the advantages for homeowners are lower maintenance and operational expenses, energy-efficient homes, enhanced indoor air quality and thermal comfort which leads to better health, reduced water consumption, adequate supply of water through rainwater harvesting, among others. Document Checklist – Mahindra Lifespaces
The full form of the OC in the Real Estate context is “Occupancy Certificate”, and its importance can't be overstated. An occupancy certificate is a document that is issued at the end of construction, by a planning authority or local government agency. OC also certifies that the construction of the building has complied with the approved plans hence stating the building/project is completed and is ready to be occupied.
A Completion Certificate (CC) is an important legal document that certifies that a building is constructed according to the laid down norms and master plan of the project.

Legal Checks, RERA and PMAY – Mahindra Lifespaces
As per RERA, “Carpet area" means the net usable floor area of an apartment, excluding the area covered by the external walls, areas under services shafts, exclusive balcony or verandah area and exclusive open terrace area, but includes the area covered by the internal partition walls of the apartment.Explanation — For the purpose of this clause, the expression "exclusive balcony or verandah area" means the area of the balcony or verandah which is appurtenant to the net usable floor area of an apartment, meant for the exclusive use of the allottee; and "exclusive open terrace area" means the area of open terrace which is appurtenant to the net usable floor area of an apartment, meant for the exclusive use of the allottee.RERA is aimed at protecting the interests of buyers in the real estate sector and establishing aims to protect buyers' interests in the real estate sector and establish rating mechanism for speedy dispute redressal.It is an act to create a mechanism that effectively regulates and addresses issues like project delivery delays, property pricing, quality of construction, title, and other changes; in an efficient and transparent manner, as set out below:
Delay in delivery of possession: The developers who default in delivery of possession will be required to pay an interest rate of 2% above State Bank of India's lending rate to the home buyers.This is aside the possibility of imprisonment of up to three years.Developers will not be able to charge for the excess area: Under RERA, ‘carpet area’ has specifically been defined.The selling of property based on super built up area has been prohibited and can only be sold based on the carpet area.Additionally, the developer will also require the consent of two-thirds of the buyers in a project before changing the project's design or any other structure.Construction Quality: The quality of the construction has been a concern for many buyers.Under RERA, any structural defect that takes place to the property for up to five years from the date of handing over possession will have to be repaired by the developer.Developers will not be able to use the money paid by flat purchasers for some other project: Under RERA, the developer will be required to transfer 70% of the money received from buyers to an escrow account.

Post which, the money will be withdrawn as per the stage of the construction, that will be approved by architect, engineer, and chartered accountant of the developer.Grievance redressal forum: Under RERA, regulatory bodies and appellate tribunals will be set up in each state to solve builder-buyer disputes.Any person aggrieved by any direction can expect a resolution from the appellate within 120 days (about 4 months).Clearances required before selling: The developers and agents will have to register themselves with the regulator, disclose every detail about the project and will be able to sell projects only after the necessary clearances have been attained.No more false promotions: Under RERA each advertisement has to carry the RERA registration number, and all the promotions and advertisements have to be completely honest without any false commitments.Developers cannot advertise a project without obtaining approval from RERA for the project.Under RERA, in case any structural defect or any other defect in artistry, quality or provision of services or any other obligations of the promoter relating to such development is brought to the notice of the promoter within a period of five years by the allottee from the date of handing over possession, subject to the terms of the agreement for sale, it shall be the duty of the promoter to rectify such defects without further charge, within thirty days, and in the event of promoter is unable to rectify such defects, the allottee shall be entitled to receive appropriate compensation in the manner as provided under the Act.

Real Estate Glossary – Mahindra Lifespaces
Under RERA, "commencement certificate" refers to the commencement certificate or the building permit or the construction permit.It is issued by the competent authority to allow or permit the promoter to begin development works on immovable property, as per the sanctioned plan.Under RERA, "completion certificate" means the completion certificate, or such other certificate, by whatever name called, issued by the competent authority certifying that the real estate project has been developed according to the sanctioned plan, layout plan and specifications, as approved by the competent authority under the local laws.‘Conveyance’ refers to the act of transferring the title, ownership, rights and interests in a property from one entity to another.The term ‘deed’ refers to an instrument, like a written document signed by all the parties to a contract, in this case, the seller and buyer.It is a binding contract that is enforceable in a court of law.A conveyance deed is, therefore, a contract in which the seller transfers all rights to the legal owner.Under RERA, an encumbrance certificate will contain the details of encumbrances on the land on which development is proposed, including any rights, title, interest, dues, litigation, details relating to mortgage/charge created for the project land and the facility taken by the Promoter or any third party and name of any party in or over such land.No Objection Certificate, popularly abbreviated as NOC, is a type of legal certificate issued by any agency, organization, institute or, in certain cases, an individual.It does not object to the covenants of the certificate.An occupancy certificate is issued by the agencies and authorities of the local government, which declares that the building is constructed as per the plans that were approved by the authorities concerned.This certificate indicates that the building is equipped with civic needs such as sanitation, water, and electricity and can be occupied.A Property Card is an extract of revenue records maintained by the State Government with respect to ownership of the land and the history of holders of land.The Indian Green Building Council or IGBC is a rating body that rates the green building projects in 4 grades, viz.Certified, Silver, Gold and Platinum, in ascending order.The rating is based on established criteria and benchmarks, hence making it easier to measure and quantify the green performance of a building.

There are 6 categories in which the building performance is measured, namely Site Measures, Water Conservation, Energy Conservation, Material Conservation, Indoor Environment Quality, and Innovation.Green Buildings:
Consume lesser resources, such as electricity and water.As compared to conventional buildings, this brings down the maintenance costs significantly.Are more comfortable for the occupants because the spaces receive lesser heat from outside due to a combination of climate-responsive design and high-performance walls, windows, and roofs.This helps reduced electricity bills for fans and air conditioning.Are naturally well-lit using daylight, which reduces the need for artificial lights during the day, thereby lowering the electricity bill for lighting.Utilize renewable energy sources such as solar and wind.Conserve water with the help of low-flow fixtures and recycling of wastewater.Help preserve natural resources such as wood and sand by using environment-friendly building materials with recycled content.Reduce the garbage directed to landfills by effective waste management strategies such as segregation at source and composting.Online Enquiry

#RediscoverYou Contest - Mahindra Lifespaces
Share your #RediscoverYou stories with us on Facebook, Instagram & Twitter and stand a chance to win a stay at Mahindra World City, Club - Chennai
Explore Mahindra World City Club, Chennai
Bedroom Aerial View Exterior View Restaurant Badminton Court Indoor Games
Contest Terms
Introduction & Eligibility
Participation in the contest implies acceptance of all the terms & conditions herein.Only Indian residents can participate in this contest.The age of the contestant should be 18 years and above and the contestant should have a social media account
The contestant should follow the Facebook, Instagram & Twitter page of Mahindra Lifespace Developers Limited (“ MLDL”)
The Contestant shall share his/her stories as a post using “#RediscoverYou” on his/her public Facebook, Instagram, or Twitter account
Entries such as “comments” or “stories” will not be entertained
There is no entry fee for this contest
Start and closing dates
The contest begins on 7th September 2022 and closes on 15th September 2022 at 11:59 PM (IST) and MLDL reserves the right to change the timing/dates/hours of the Contest without any prior intimation to the participants
The shortlisted contestants’ details will be declared on 30th September 2022 and the same is solely at the discretion of MLDL and shall be final and binding
Judging
Only 3 winners will be selected on the final shortlisted entries received on all platforms (Facebook, Instagram & Twitter).The winners will be chosen based on the maximum votes received on the final post as comments, after the initial shortlisting.In case of a tie between the contestants, the MLDL team will select the winner as per the entry received first.If a participant does not meet the eligibility criteria or is subject to any entry restrictions, he/she will be disqualified without any notice.MLDL’s decision in respect of the competition will be final and no correspondence will be entered into
Winners and prizes
The prize for the competition is “one day (1) Stay in MWC Club at Mahindra World City, Chennai”.The declared winner will get a Stay Voucher for the Prize from MLDL.The stay includes accommodation for 2 Adults + 2 kids (Inclusive of the winner).Children below five years can be accompanied.Breakfast, Lunch, and Dinner for the day will be provided.This prize cannot be exchanged for cash or any other consideration.The validity of Prize coupon will be valid from 1st October 2022 to 30th October 2022.

Booking for the stay will be subject to availability, dates will have to be confirmed directly with MWC Club at Mahindra World City, Chennai.The winner of the Contest must comply with the terms and conditions of the Contest.If any Contest winner does not respond within 5 business days, the prize will be forfeited, and another winner will be chosen by MLDL without any notice.If MLDL is unable to reach/contact the winner, then MLDL shall have the absolute discretion to deal with such a prize as it deems fit and/or selects an alternative Winner.MLDL is not responsible for the travel expenses of the winner(s).The winner(s) shall have to make their own arrangements for their travel at their own costs and expenses.The winners shall be required to produce/submit valid Government id photo identity/address proof at the time of claiming the Prize.

Participants/winners may be required to participate in a photo, video, and/or film session organised by MLDL, and the Participants/winner(s) acknowledge that MLDL has the absolute and exclusive right to use such publicity photos, videos and/or films in any medium and in any reasonable manner it may deem fit without any consideration or payment of similar nature to such participants/winner(s). MLDL reserves the right to disqualify any participant/winner if it has reasonable grounds to believe the participant/winner has breached any of these Terms and Conditions. Employees of MLDL and Employees of its holding company(s), affiliate(s) subsidiaries, sponsors, associated agencies, participating operators, and their immediate family members and relatives, or anyone else connected with the creation or administration of the promotion are not eligible to participate in this contest.   now
